history_info_1.conntent_1: Alexander the Great was accidentally buried alive
history_info_1.conntent_2: Scientists believe that Alexander the Great suffered from a neurological disorder called Guillain-Barré Syndrome. They also believe that when he was thought to be dead, he was actually paralyzed and mentally aware of everything.

history_info_2.conntent_1: Pope Gregory IV declared war on cats
history_info_2.conntent_2: Pope Gregory IV declared war on cats in the 13th century. He said that black cats were instruments of the devil. Because of this belief, he ordered the extermination of these felines throughout Europe. However, this plan backfired as it caused an increase in the population of plague-carrying rats.

history_info_3.conntent_1: In the 1940s, a piece of clothing led to attacks
history_info_3.conntent_2: In the 1940s, according to the Smithsonian website, Zoot Suits (loose pants and jacket) were commonly worn by Latino, Black, and other men. However, what some saw as a fashion statement, others viewed as an insult to America and its soldiers. As a result, according to historical sources, the summer of 1943 made world headlines with attacks on these minority communities in Los Angeles. To stop the attacks, the Los Angeles City Council banned Zoot Suits.

history_info_4.conntent_1: The Anglo-Zanzibar War is the shortest war in history
history_info_4.conntent_2: The 1896 Anglo-Zanzibar War began after the signing of the Heligoland-Zanzibar Treaty between Britain and Germany in 1890. After Zanzibar was declared a protectorate of the British Empire, Britain installed its own sultan to control it: Sultan Hamad bin Thuwaini. However, the sultan suddenly died in 1896, and Sultan Khalid bin Barghash took the throne without consulting Britain. Britain was not happy with this situation, so they asked him to step down. The new sultan refused to abdicate, and the British bombarded the palace. The conflict ended in 38 minutes.

history_info_5.conntent_1: There used to be female Gladiators
history_info_5.conntent_2: A female gladiator was called a Gladiatrix, or Gladiatrices in plural. They were rarer than their male counterparts. Gladiatrices had duties such as executing criminals, fighting other Gladiators, and fighting animals in Rome's various fighting pits.

history_info_6.conntent_1: History's most successful pirate was a woman
history_info_6.conntent_2: This woman, named Ching Shih, was an escort in China until the Commander of the Red Flag Fleet bought and married her. However, rather than seeing her merely as a wife, he saw her as his equal, and she became an active pirate commander in the fleet.

history_info_7.conntent_1: The Persians used cats to stop an Egyptian attack in 525 BC
history_info_7.conntent_2: Those who know something about ancient Egypt will recognize that Egyptians respected cats and some even worshipped them (they even had a cat goddess named Bastet). During the Battle of Pelusium, the invading Persian Army led by Cambyses II won a crucial phase of the battle by taking advantage of Egyptian religion. According to Macedonian historian Polyaenus, the Persian Commander ordered his soldiers to use 'sacred' cats to protect themselves from Egyptian attack. Although the Persian victory was an inevitable outcome, they saved many soldiers by using this tactic. Herodotus wrote that only 7,000 Persians fell in the battle, while more than 50,000 Egyptians lost their lives.

history_info_8.conntent_2: In 1487, more than 20,000 people were sacrificed in rituals at the Aztec temple.

history_info_9.conntent_2: The last cavalry unit was used during World War II. 2,000 Mongolian cavalrymen who attacked a German infantry unit were killed, while no German soldiers died.

history_info_10.conntent_1: Many cities had bathhouses from the Roman Empire
history_info_10.conntent_2: It would not be fair to look at people who lived in the Middle Ages as 'never having bathed'. This misconception most likely stems from the church's opposition to the mixed baths that were common during the Roman period. In reality, the church had bathhouses built near churches and pilgrimage sites, separate for women and men. Being able to bathe at home was a privilege for the wealthy.
